So, the mistakes in this code is about indices. Your code is giving an out of bound error.

1) In line 19, when you do arr3[i]=arr[i], you know that arr only have length a, so it cannot have index till a+b.

2) In line 25, except of doing i<=a+b, do i<a+b.

Please make a habit to take care of the indices of the arrays when writing a code.

I am incredulous about the way you have defined these things. Are you sure you aren't just being pompous here? Such bogs are vile to the succinct resources I have prepared in the past

I didn't quite understand what you wanted to say, but this blog was written for the version of the problem in which we have infinite amounts of each item. But, if we have a limited amount of each item then we can build a frequency array (or map) of each item. We will calculate the polynomial based on the frequency array then. If $$$a$$$ is the freq array (or map) then the polynomial for $$$a_i$$$ is:

$$$p_i(z) = 1 + z^{i} + z^{2i} + ... + z^{i\cdot a_i}$$$

From now on, the solution is pretty much the same.

blogEntry.title: A proof that the GCD(even sum, odd sum) > 1 for a consecutive set of integers.

comment.text: Auto comment: topic has been updated by Banda. (previous revision, new revision, compare).

blogEntry.title: A proof that the GCD(even sum, odd sum) > 1 for a consecutive set of integers.

comment.text:
for each letter in the alphabet, you create two arrays: the array $$$pos$$$ and the array $$$rev$$$, the first array correspond to the initial positions of all occurrences of the letter we are processing and the second array correspond to the reversed positions. Then greedily it's easy to prove that the resulting position of the left-most character in $$$pos$$$ will be the left-most value in the array $$$rev$$$, so you just need to reverse the array $$$rev$$$ and you get the resulting positions for the corresponding letter.

for example if you have the string "aabbba" the array $$$pos$$$ will be $$${0, 1, 5}$$$ and the array $$$rev$$$ will be $$${5, 4, 0}$$$, so the resulting positions are $$$0\rightarrow 0, 1\rightarrow4, 5\rightarrow5$$$.

Here my submission.
